data.message: Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out on Wednesday. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!

Hello TSP members! That last post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email today for our first follow-up survey. You'll receive a $20 gift card upon completion!We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!
Wow, time flies by fast
#90: Pass the torch! What advice would you give to other smokers who are trying to quit? #support
If i can do it, so can you. Its a matter if you want to or not.
Don't give up!
#89: After your quit date, go to the dentist and have your teeth cleaned! Is there anyone you wouldn’t mind kissing with a fresh mouth? ;) #reinforcement
Lol my husband
My girl friend :p
#88: How else will your life be different when you're living smoke free? Tell us some of the things you're most excited for in the future! #knowyourself
That picture pretty much explains everything.
My son will be proud of me one day

#85: If you're having trouble shaking those smoky-thoughts, play the Milk-Off game and reset your mind to overcome cravings. After five minutes of playing, did you feel a difference? #reinforcement http://www.milk-off.com/
Not sure what the milk off game is but clicking the link didn't really lead me anywhere
Same
10153 and 10169, we apologize that the link didn't work for you. It may be an issue with accessing by mobile -- the game works best on a computer. Feel free to give it a try!-Shirley from TSP

#86: The night before your Quit Date, make sure you've gotten rid of all your cigarettes, lighters, matches and ashtrays from your car and home. Would/did you do this? If you can, take a picture of your night-before purge and post it here. #control
I would

A little late but just cleaned my truck out real clean and smelling good. All the ashes an ashtray are out. Smoking in it always leaves ashes and a bad smell so now I plan to keep it smelling good an clean cigarette free
Lookin' good, 10153! :)
#87: What are you gaining by quitting? Anyone got a savings jar? #reinforcement

I'm gaining a life lung cancer free. A healthier me. I'm gaining nothing better for myself with smoking.At the end of the week I've been  using the 50 or 60 bucks I'd spend on cigarettes  and take my Lil family out to eat or do something  Fridays or saturdays
My health

#84: Your smoking-substitutions can give you time to do things you haven't gotten around to. Choose one of the following that you'd like to do instead of smoke, or tell us your own. #feelinghealthy:• Do puzzles or crafts if you’re used to smoking while watching TV• Eat raw vegetables, like carrot sticks• Read a book or magazine
Reading books
Play with ma lil boy. Play ma xbox. Umm watch a movie maybe

Hi Everyone, I am switching things up and doing The Doctor Is In a bit later this week. What are people dealing with this week? Has anyone in this group tried to quit smoking? If so, how did it go? If not, what is getting in your way?

I like to leave you guys with tips in these session, so today, here is our 5-step TSP quit plan. See if something resonates with you: 1. GET READY.• Set a quit date and stick to it – not even a single puff! 2. GET SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT.• Tell your family, friends and coworkers you are quitting.• Talk to your doctor or other health care provider.• Get group, individual, or telephone counseling. Think about who can support you with quitting smoking3. LEARN NEW SKILLS AND BEHAVIORS.• When you first try to quit, change your routine.• Reduce stress.• Distract yourself from urges to smoke.• Plan something enjoyable to do every day.• Drink a lot of water and other fluids. Think about which of these will be most helpful to you?4. GET MEDICATION AND USE IT CORRECTLY.Talk with your health care provider about which medication will work best for you:• Medication: bupropion, verenicline (prescription).• Nicotine Replacement:-gum and patch are over-the-counter-inhaler and nasal spray are prescriptionIs there one of these that you think would be helpful for you?5. BE PREPARED FOR RELAPSE OR DIFFICULT SITUATIONS.• Avoid alcohol.• Be careful around other smokers.• Improve your mood in ways other than smoking.• Eat a healthy diet and stay active.
#83: Planning ahead can make all the difference for quitting. Tell us your plan for resisting nicotine cravings during nighttime after your quit date. #control
Usually  right after I eat dinner is my strongest craving. And then after that I'll sit on ma porch fr a while and light another one up before I go back inside
Go to sleep

#82: Do you think Obama is lifting his mood with a quick 5-minute call to a friend? Studies say calling someone to offer support can motivate you as well. So who will you call during your next 5 spare minutes? #reinforcement
I don't really have anyone  to rely on. But if I could talk to Obama for 5 min and give him a piece of my mind that would make me forget about ciggarettes. Lol
Depends on what kind of "friend"he is calling lol. I would probably call my grandma

#81: When you're stressed out at work or in class, how will you get through cigarette cravings? Countdown relaxation techniques can be helpful, but what are YOU planning on doing when things get crazy? #control
Eat, eat, and eat.
Yes! Food is the solution

data.message: #79: A common trigger for ex-smokers: driving or getting stuck in traffic. You could chew sugarless gum or listen to the radio to combat your craving. What else could you do instead of smoking when you're behind the wheel? #control
Those are the only two ideas I can think of that wouldn't be considered 'dangerous'
Prolly play on ma phone tbh
Please be careful! :)

#80: Before your Quit Date arrives, take some time to think about your afternoon routine and how you will change it to keep you from giving in to cravings. Post your strategy here and maybe inspire someone else in the group! #control
My routine is the same, except without smoking.
Extra school work, chores, or play time with my baby.
#78: Try going about your day without carrying around your matches or lighter. Tell us what it was like being without your trusty flame and how it prepared you for your quit day. #feelinghealthy
I've tried it before and as long as I'm busy I'm fine but I do like to keep it around anyway whether I use them or not
Done this before. Having one around doesn't really trigger me
#77: A common trigger for many smokers is waking up in the morning. Showering right away when you wake up is one way to interrupt this common smoking trigger. How would you do it? #control
Just resist the urge
I actually dont have the urge to smoke right when I wake up. I already got a dry mouth as it is. Usually when I drunk my coffee is when I have that first urge. I just keep resisting myself.

I want to leave you guys with a post about visual imagery that can help if you are having cravings to smoke and don't want to (or can't). As an experiment this week, try this and see if it can be helpful to you.
Hi Everyone, I'm here for the next hour to answer any questions or chat about smoking and quitting. What triggers to smoke have you guys been dealing with lately?

#76: To prepare for your Quit Date, think about how you will handle mornings without cigarettes. Post your answers to our questions here and keep them handy for that morning when you might need them! #control
Use mouthwash instead of a morning cigarette
Not stop at the store an busy any. Keep myself busy at work. Just anything to do to keep my mind off of it

Alright! I can do it!
I've don't it already and it feels great knowing  you just went 24 hours with not one cigarette. First couple of days are hard

Take a pic of yours and show it off here, or tell us what you’re putting in it! #control
I don't think thats something i myself am willing to di
That would just be another thing for my son to get into so I will pass on it

#73: What could a friend or family member do to help you stay on the Quit Wagon? Choose your favorite option below (or come up with your own), then ask for it from a supporter! What kind of response did you get? #support • Be available to call or hang out when you feel the urge to smoke• Help you clean your home or car so they no longer smell like smoke• Send you weekly emails asking how you’re doing and reminding you of your reasons to quit
My mom can totally come and help clean my house.
Being able to hang out with me is best
#72: Let all your FB friends know about your mission to be smoke-free. Share with us what kinds of reactions your friends had. #support
I dont want everyone to know in the first place that I did smoke. I'm sure I would get support, though.
Same here.They will be more suprised that I smoke than me quitting

#71: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I gave myself one treat for each week that I didn’t smoke. One week I bought myself flowers, the next I took a friend out to the movies, and the next I bought myself a sweater. Next week, I’m going to a concert." Share how will you reward yourself when you quit! #reinforcement
Im gunna go fishing
Food!

#70: Research says that people who practice gratitude have greater peace of mind, happiness, physical health, and deeper, more satisfying personal relationships. Try taking 5 minutes today to write down what you're grateful for and post what you appreciated here. #reinforcement
My son, my husband, and all of the good things we have that show that we have what we need and also a few luxuries.
My son.My family. My house and luxuries.My job And being american

Hi Guys, I am doing The Dr Is In sessions today instead of Johannes Thrul. I am an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at UCSF in San Francisco and creator of TSP. Happy to answer any questions you have - I'm here for an hour. Also let's use tho time to support each other with quitting. Who is trying to quit right now in this group?
Is Dr. Thrul okay?
Fine - out of town. Thanks for asking, I am sure he would love to know that you did. Have you been getting something useful out of the sessions with him?
I've talked a few times with him- he is very easy to talk to and insightful. I've enjoyed him
That's great. So happy to hear it. What specifically are you dealing with now related to smoking that we at TSP could help with?

Nothing really. I've just been cutting back more and more and it has been successful so far. Telling myself that I don't want them since I know that I don't need them. I never smoked a whole lot to begin with, so I don't have extreme withdrawal symptoms so far.
Well that's good to hear. Glad that it's working for you. Is you ultimate goal to be completely smoke free?
Yes
Cool, well keep up the good work. If cutting down works, keep doing it. If you can set a date for have that last puff and then not smoke any more, that is ideal...
Gotta run, but I will be here two more weeks and we can follow-up on anything else you are thinking about or questions before Johannes Thrul is back. Great chatting today!

data.message: #69: Even the most willing friends may need some direction for how they can help you best. How could your friends help you quit smoking for good? Post your ideas here. #support
My friends could care less but not smoking around me would be nice
Not smoking around me and listening when I need to vent

#68: Making it more difficult to smoke is good preparation for the challenges you'll face when you quit. Try keeping your smokes out of reach for 24 hours and tell us how it affected your day. #feelinghealthy
Id rather just not buy em or have em to begin with. If i knew where they are at i will be more conscious to go an get one
That actually causes more stress to not have them around. I keep them around so I don't have to tell myself I can't have them. I just tell myself I don't want them.

#67: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I had my car detailed; it smelled like new and really made me not want to smoke in it anymore!" Would cleaning your car motivate you to stay quit? Tell us why (or why not). #reinforcement
Yes because I like clean and nicely fragrant cars.
It would help
#66: If you're tired, hungry, or cranky, taking just five minutes to refresh yourself with water or a snack can make all the difference. Tell us how you plan to refresh yourself today! #reinforcement
When I get a little angry, I will eat a snickers
Go to the gym

#65: Many new quitters put on a few pounds because of the metabolism-shock. Keeping healthy snacks on hand can help you keep your weight under control. What’s your favorite healthy snack or recipe? #feelinghealthy
Apples an oranges
Celery and peanut butter, watermelon and mandarins
#64: When you're a nonsmoker, what will be different about your daily life? Tell us what you're looking forward to! #knowyourself
My lung capacity.Not coughing up stuff.
No smoke smell on my clothes

#63: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I bought myself a new CD for each week that I stayed smoke-free." Do you feel like your iTunes collection could use some new editions? #reinforcement
I don't need more music, but other little goodies for myself would be nice
Instead of music, I would wanna reward myself with something else.
Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
I'd smoke if I were agitated, nervous, pissed off. Mood for sure plays a role in smoking
Agreed 10153 - those are big time triggers. Are you still quit? What kind of strategies do you use to cope with these situations without a cig?
I kind of relapsed this past weekend. Drinking is a big time trigger for me. I haven't smoked but may 5 cigarettes since saturday.

Thanks for sharing 10153. Lapses can definitely be part of the smoking cessation process and it's normal to feel bad or ashamed about a lapse after it happened. What was the situation like? What triggered the smoking? And how do you plan to continue?
Well. We were having a get together at my house. And I was drinking a little bit. That's a bad trigger for me but it was a celebration. And people were smoking so I joined in.
Ok, yeah I see how this would be a high risk situation. How have you been doing since then? Have you smoked at all?
Yeah. A few here an there.
Ok, so how do you feel about quitting right now? Are you still committed to staying smoke free?
Absolutely.

That's great! Just look at all the progress you have made since you first quit. You managed to stay smoke free for many weeks in a row and learned a lot about how to control your smoking. I think you should just go back to where you were before this lapse and stop smoking altogether again. Are you motivated to do that? If not what barriers are in the way?
Sorry guys, I've got to run. I'll be traveling for the next couple of weeks so my colleague Dr. Danielle Ramo will take over and hold office hours. Have a great time and see you later!

#62: When you can't escape worry and anxiety, take five minutes to ground yourself in the present moment and replenish your motivation. Try it, then report back how things went when you took 5. #reinforcement
It has worked well before
^^Same here

#61: When you're a new quitter, giving yourself time to let frustrations pass can be a lifesaver. What are some of your best strategies to de-stress? Tell us here and see if someone inspires you! #control
Excercise, cleaning, playing with my baby or my phone.
Play with ma lil boy, shoot the guns, ride dirtbikes, fishing, that's always stress relieving.
#60: When your cravings are getting bad, call someone you trust. Tell them how you’re feeling and that you don’t want to smoke. Try it out and let us know how it went. #feelinghealthy
My friends are hateful and will prolly tell me to stop being a wimp
He said to quit doing it then.

#56: Great smoking-substitutions can help you break the smoking associations you've developed. I chew a toothpick. Stay away from other smokers.
I use mouthwash more frequently than any normal person would lol and I don't smoke in the car I do eat more and I do frequently go to no smoking zones
What do you guys like about smoking? #TDII
I liked the high it gave me when I smoked my first one.

#55: Half the battle of quitting is breaking cigarette associations. So change up your routines: drink your morning coffee outside or switch to tea. How are you going to mix things up to make them new again? #control
I've changed my morning cigarette to mouthwash instead, and also for my evening one. It's going pretty well.
After I eat I chew on toothpicks to fight that urge

I figured it didn’t cost any more than my cigarettes would have, and I felt like it was a gift to myself for making a fresh, nonsmoking start".  Would you ever do the same as this ex-smoker? #healthyliving

data.message: #49: Lots of ex-smokers report that a common trigger for them was when they were hungry. Is this true for you? Will you be packing healthy snacks to help lessen the cravings, or are you planning something different? Tell us! #control

Wasn't a problem to me. I just want food when I'm hungry

You guys told us at the beginning of this study you wanted to quit within the next 30 days. Now that we are halfway into the study, I was wondering if anyone of you may be ready to set a quit date? (Experts agree this is the most effective way to quit for good) #TDII
10132 - a while back we had talked about setting a quit date. How are you doing? How did it go?
10153 - feel free to share your story. How did you do it? I think we can learn a lot from your example!

#48: Recent quitters may put on weight for two reasons.1) Without nicotine, your metabolism returns to a normal, slower speed.2) You may eat more to combat the urge to smoke.Is weight gain a big concern for you as you quit? Why or why not? #feelinghealthy
For me. Nahh
Not for me. I have always had a very fast metabolism, even before smoking. And I usually eat a lot anyway. A few extra pounds (if I did gain any) isn't gonna hurt me lol

#45: Yesterday we posted about betting a friend. How about quitting WITH a friend? Quitting with a friend can drastically increase your chances of staying quit. Take a chance, ask a friend who also smokes if they would ever try to quit with you. What did they say? #support
Trying to get my gf to quit..but she's having a harder time than I am
They said no
Thanks for trying!

#47: The night before your Quit Date, reflect on the fact that tomorrow will be your first day free from your cigarette addiction. Tell us how you plan to reflect on this moment before you fall asleep. #control
I told myself I will not stop at the gas station before work, cause that's usually when I bought cigarettes
Laying in my bed, feeling good about it.

data.message: #42: Social situations can be a tricky place for new quitters, especially when alcohol is involved. But you want a social life, right? So practice how you'll decline a smoke before you go out. How would you pass on a cigarette if alcohol is involved? #control
Walk with two drinks in my hand. Can't hold a cigarette if your holding two drinks right?!
Smoking is one of the furthest things from my mind when I'm drinking lol

Did you know that you can avoid almost all of the negative long-term health consequences of smoking if you quit before you are 30 years old? Does that change how you feel about smoking and quitting? #TDII
Interesting.
Here is some more information on the health benefits of quitting.
How are you holding up 10153?
Holding strong.
Great - I'm glad to hear that 10153! Any difficult situations you have encountered lately?
Yeah my gf won't stop smoking. But I tell her to stay away from me with them

Well at least she's respectful and supporting you that way. It can be hard to stomach sometimes but it's her decision if she wants to quit or continue smoking. The good thing is that you are setting a great example for her though and she will come around eventually - you just have to be patient and supportive :)
Regarding my original post: Check out this study if you want to learn more about it: http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128
See you tomorrow for session 5.

#41: Sometimes, less is more. Today, try smoking only half of each cigarette. Here’s a tip: instead of lighting a whole cigarette and stopping halfway, break half of it off first then finish it. How did it go? Do you think you could do this for all future cigs? #feelinghealthy
I've tried it, but it tastes horrible when you come back for it.
I know cigarettes are a waste of money as they are..but I don't think I could spend 5 bucks on a pack and snap em all in half. I'd just buy the shorter cigarettes instead.

#40: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I spent extra time doing things just for me: taking a long bath, reading a good book, or taking a nap. I’m doing a great job at quitting. I deserve to treat myself well!" How would you treat yourself once YOU quit? #reinforcement
I am going to do the same thing- enjoy the things I love longer and treat myself with really good food
^lol yes foood.Food taste a lot better after quitting for a while.
We agree! ^_^

#39: Taking five minutes to sit and breathe can enhance your well-being, mood, attention and mental focus. Some time today when you’re feeling stressed, just take 5 mins to breath and tell us if it worked for you. #reinforcement
It does work. Like a quick meditation.
Yes
Yes

Lol same here ^ and get a nice cold drink afterwards

data.caption: The Doctor Is In

data.message: #23: We’ve been posting about different NRTs for a few days. Here’s a summary of several quit methods. Which one do you think would be best to help you quit smoking and why? #beingconscious http://tobacco-cessation.org/whatworkstoquit/NTCCguide.pdf
Self help and talking to someone about it- you have to make the decision to help yourself, and also you need moral support to help get you through the tough parts.
Cold turkey

#28: Ready to commit to quitting? If yes, pick a date to quit smoking for good! Post it here, or create a group event and invite everyone in this group. Everytime you check Facebook, you’ll be reminded that someone is making the change with you. #freeyourself
I dont have a set date, although I am working on it.
I've already quit for the past few weeks
#31: Holding out on your next smoke is great practice for when you quit smoking. Try it out for a day and report back how it felt to know you can handle more time without smoking. #feelinghealthy
I've been doing that and it feels good to know that you can go a long time without wanting to go smoke
I've been doing it for a while now

Hello TSP members! We have tallied up your comments for the first 30 posts. Feel free to message us to find out how much you've earned! Remember, you must have commented on ALL 30 posts to receive money.

#30: The following post was made by a successful quitter: "I focused every day on another way that I felt better. One day, I’d notice how much easier it was to breathe, and another day I would realize how I could walk up the stairs without getting winded. Reminding myself each day about what I was getting out of quitting made it seem worthwhile." How do you think you'll notice your body getting healthier when you quit? #healthyliving
We apologize for the late post.-Shirley from TSP
I've noticed that I have been in better moods, and that my temper has been better maintained. I generally feel better about myself.

As someone who goes to the gym reguraly, I notice I'm not so winded easily. I've even put on a few pounds now. My blood pressure is lower. Right now I've been coughing up stuff out of my lungs though.
#29: Post what happened when you told one (or a few) friends about your plan to quit. #support
A few said I won't quit and it won't last.
I haven't told anyone- this is for myself to know until it's over.

#24: Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or NRT’s (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit.  What are your thoughts on e-cigs? Have/would you ever try one? #ecig

I've tried a few of them, but it wasn't good for me. I enjoyed the 'smoke' that came out of it and the light that came on, but it had no end to it. When smoking a regular cigarette it has a time limit, unlike an ecig. I would constantly puff on it, and still did not get that satisfaction that I did when smoking a real one.
It's not a very good replacment in my opinion.
Thanks for sharing! :)
#27: Yesterday we asked you to tell us how confident you were that you COULD quit smoking. What would it take to get you from the number you said yesterday to ONE NUMBER HIGHER? #motivation
That would be number 11 for me. I feel more than confident I will quit smoking.I guess to know I could quote all together is to totally isolate myself from the world.
Stress relief!

data.caption: Session 3 - Smoking cessation advice
data.description: Hi guys, as I will be traveling for the rest of the week I will hold session 3 today. We will talk more about social support and quitting. Hope you can make it - see you later.

data.message: #26: We understand that stopping smoking is not easy. On a scale of 1-10, how confident are you that you COULD quit smoking if you tried? #motivation

#18: This over-the-counter Nicotine Replacement Therapy looks like cough drops and can help alleviate withdrawal symptoms during work or class. Would you try this method? Why or why not? #beingconscious
No for the same reasons I have said before
No thanks.
#19: Would you consider using a nicotine inhaler to quit smoking? Why or why not? #beingconscious
I've never even heard of this before.
No. I don't want to try anything to get off of what I am already doing, so I don't have to quit 2 things instead of 1.

#20: When withdrawal symptoms are at their worst, a nasal spray can be a quick and convenient way to pack a punch to those cravings. Would you ever use a nicotine nasal spray? Why or why not? #beingconscious
Not a nicotine spray, but perhaps a regular saline spray for a placebo.
I don't like injecting things into my nose so no thanks.
#21: How do you feel about this medication that changes its dose of nicotine to match the intensity of your withdrawal symptoms? Would any of you consider using varenicline? #beingconscious
Looks like a good marketing scheme to me. Cause most of the people get these and don't commit and wasted their money.Cold turkey is no better way in my opinion.
No.
#22: What have you heard about bupropion to help people stop smoking? Would you consider taking a medication to help you quit? #beingconscious
No thanks
Nope
#25: Is this your first attempt at quitting? If not, what worked/didn’t work for you in the past? Share your story here. #eyesontheprize

No this is not my first attempt My first attempt of quitting smoking I started dipping as a substitute. It worked for a while actually, but what I didn't like was the nasty cold sores in my mouth. I didn't want holes in my gums either.
I've tried before wth quitting cold turkey, but I caught an awful case of pneumonia two weeks after and gave in to a craving. Now I'm trying to quit again.
#16: What do you know about the patch as a type of Nicotine Replacement Therapy? Have/would you ever use it? #beingconscious

I don't know much about it, but I don't want to use it. I'd rather just stop what I'm doing than to need a crutch to get off of it. Then I would have two things I would need to quit using rather than just one.
Nope
#17: What have you heard about nicotine gum? Do you think you’d try it? #beingconscious
All I've heard is that it tastes horrible
I don't want to try it for the same reasons as the patch
Nope
How does your smoking affect your loved ones, kids, or significant other? What do they think about your smoking? #TDII
No one knows except very few friends and my partner, but they don't judge because they all smoke too. My son is too young to form an opinion about it.
Thanks for sharing 10169. How are those plans to cut down working out we talked about last week?

It's going pretty well- I've chosen to substitute the morning cigarette for mouthwash although some mornings I have not done so good because those mornings had a rough start. I have given up smoking in the car completely and have done really well at waiting out a craving.

That's great to hear - good job! I think it's pretty normal that not everything will work perfectly starting out, but you learn something new every day and are becoming more successful. Also, it's the fact that you are working on it that counts! Which are still the most difficult for you to get rid of?

Well the morning one is not so bad now- the worst one now is when I get extremely stressed to the point where I don't know what else to do and nothing else works. I will have to try harder to beat that one.
What strategy have you been trying that worked best so far and what could you do differently in the future that may work even better?

I've just been trying distractions like playing with my baby, exercising and deep breathing. It's hard to resist the urge to smoke when you are in postpartum depression but I have been working really hard at it. I think that tomorrow I am going to limit the amount I smoke even more by setting out only three that I can have if I really want one for the entire day and night. I believe that will force me to get creative with my usual methods and do even better. My son has been more cheerful today which put me in a great mood so I haven't even used three cigarettes all day long.

Very good - I am really impressed! It's also great that you are noticing patterns in your daily mood and your smoking - this shows you that some pleasant activities each day can really help with reducing/quitting. I am logging off for today, but keep up the good work and try those creative strategies and I will check in with you next week to see how you are doing. Have a great week!
Thanks and you too

Smoking doesn't help with Ma lil man having a small case of asthma. We don't smoke around him but it's just time away from being with him when we wanted to take a smoke break. I am completely dedicated to throw this habit away. My girlfriend on the other hand is not as dedicated. Which doesn't help much with me.

data.caption: Session 2 - Smoking cessation advice
data.description: This week, I will also continue with the special smoking cessation advice sessions. Session 2 will happen on Thursday. Stop by if you are interested in some extra tips on how to quit or just want to see what the session is like. We will talk about high risk situations for smoking and how you can counter them. Feel free to have a look at session 1 from last week in the meantime. See you!

data.message: How do you feel about your quitting now? Still feeling committed to becoming smoke free? #TDII
Yes- I still have the " want to" and I have cut down to about 4 cigarettes a day. I am feeling pretty good about it.
I am happy to hear that 10169! Good job! What strategy to cut down have you been using so far and how do you plan to cut down even further?

I have been simply asking myself did I really want one or did I just want to stay in my routine and smoke when I usually do. I plan on continuing this until I feel I no longer really want one. It doesn't feel like a need- just a strong want. So as long as I cut back when I feel like I want one, I will be fine.

Very good 10169 - one thing I would like to mention: Cravings usually get a lot better after 5 min, so your strategy to ask yourself if you really want one is spot on. A lot of times the craving will just go away after a while. Here is a comprehensive list of other strategies I would like to share with you: http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-living/quit-smoking/in-depth/nicotine-craving/art-20045454 Anything you think may be useful for you?

I believe that the getting physical and the distraction techniques are really working well for me. I can't really ask family for help (although they have been helping without knowing it) because I am one of those closet smokers like the article mentioned. Not a lot of people know about my habit because I conceal it well. That is why it won't be as hard for me to quit- when I am with people I don't want to know about my habit, I can go a few days without smoking, or however long I am around them.
Great - good to hear that your family is providing support without even knowing :) Which cigarettes do you think will be the hardest for you to give up and what can you do to give them up anyway?
Definitely the first one of the morning and when I have met my stress limit. I can just try to avoid the one in the morning and try some other relaxation method when I am stressed.

Those are great ideas 10169! I recommend to try deep breathing relaxation techniques for stressful situations. Also I think changing your routines may help. If you smoke your first one in the day in a particular situations (e.g., with your first coffee) try having your coffee in a different situations where you can't smoke - just an example but I think you know what I mean. How does this sound?

That would be great if I did drink coffee lol! But no, it's the very first thing I do in the morning. I will just have to find a new thing to do when I first get up to get awake for the day. It sounds like a great idea to change what I do so that I can create a new routine. Thank you for the tip!
Sure - you're welcome. Yes try it and let me know how it goes next week! Here are some additional tips for dealing with withdrawal that you may find helpful. Keep up the good work!

One additional thought I have: Maybe you can try brushing your teeth or use mouthwash or something like that first thing when you get up and that first cigarette may not be as appealing anymore. Just an idea.

Those tips are great although I will not be trying to eat candy as I don't like candy. I love juice and tea, and love to be active, so I will definitely be improving on those. I usually brush my teeth and mouthwash right after that cigarette, but I will skip that and just go straight to oral hygiene starting tomorrow. Thanks again and I will let you know how it goes.
Great - talk to you next week then! You can do it :)

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Getting Ready to Quit 4.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: I'll be doing another session Q&A this week. Looking forward to seeing you there!

data.message: #10: What are your top reasons for quitting? #freeyourself
I'm quitting so my son wont be around smoke and that he won't be as likely to pick up the habit.

1. For my son. Would not like him to grow up to pick up a bad habit. 2. For my self. To prove that i can kick this habit goodbye. 4. For my health. We all know it's bad for you. I can't stand how hard to it to catch my breath now after doing so  little of anything streneous. I wanna be able to go jog with ought dying. Go to the gym without feeling so winded on leg day. 5. My family. If I can prove to them I can quit then the ones that do smoke can hopefully understand it's not as bad as it seems.6. My wallet. It's like bailing water out of an already sinking ship. I could spend my hard earned money on better things than a pack of smokes.7. I don't wanna smell like an ash tray anymore. 8. I don't want the smokers cough anymore. 9. I don't wanna miss out on anything anymore due to having to step ouside to have a smoke. 10. I don't want to feel like an addict anymore
Thank you for sharing! We're so impressed by all these motivating factors.
#15: Gradually reducing the amount you smoke can also lead to quitting. Do you think gradual reduction could be right for you? #beingconscious
Yes, so I don't get sick again as I did when I tried to quit cold turkey.
Cold turkey is working out for me so far.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Getting Ready to Quit 4.
data.name: Session 1 - Smoking cessation advice
data.caption: Session 1 - Smoking cessation advice
data.description: Hi everyone, this week I will be starting with our special sessions to give you even more support and extra tips to quit smoking! We have designed a total of 6 sessions and each one will last approximately 45 minutes. In these sessions, I will work with each of you to come up with your own specific quit plan. All of this is going to happen on the wall of this event and I look forward to seeing you there! Please let me know if you have any questions.

data.message: #14: Historically, most successful quitters chose this approach. Learn about withdrawal symptoms and cravings at the link below and tell us if you plan to use this method. Why or why not? #beingconscious http://www.webmd.com/smoking-cessation/quit-smoking

I stopped cold turkey yesterday. And I honestly believe it's the best way if you want to quit. I haven't found anything that can really replace the feeling of smoking a cigarette. Ita been tough but I've been having just strong will power
No. I have my reasons for not quitting cold turkey, and I am going to take it slowly.

#13: Asking you to go out and party, even though they know drinking is a trigger, would NOT be helpful. Joking about how long you’ll stay on the quit wagon would NOT be helpful. What other things could you ask your friends NOT to do to keep you on the right path? #support
Blow smoke in my face..or smoke around me in general.
Same ^^
Hi guys, with spring being finally here, I am curious to hear what your smoking looks like during this time of the year? Do you smoke more or less? #TDII
Well it will be a lot less this year considering I didn't smoke a cigarette at all today. Today was day one. But I'd still smoke the same reguardless no less or no more I guess.
I usually smoke less the warmer it gets
Great job 10153! Glad to hear you have decided to give it a try! How is your day going so far?
10169, so this is a time when you naturally cut back on your smoking then? How much do you currently smoke?
I usually smoke about 6 cigarettes a day, but when it gets warmer I don't want them as much because I have other distractions.
That's a great start 10169. What are the things that work best for you to distract you from smoking?

Well not too bad. I don't feel any difference in mood or behavior. I wanted to smoke but I just kept saying no to myself. I just kept myself busy doing something else instead of using the time to smoke.

Outside activities like atv riding, fishing, and walking. Being inside during the winter creates boredom and the urge to smoke. I find that if I spend my time outside and have fun I don't think about it nearly as much.
Very good 10153 - I am really impressed by your willpower! Do you have people you can lean on for support when things get tough? What are some other strategies you could use when the craving hits?

Those are some spot on observations 10169! So it sounds like boredom and having nothing to do are really your high risk situations for smoking. It also sounds like getting outdoors is a very effective strategy for you to not smoke. What else could you do to distract yourself when you are craving a smoke and can't go on a hike for example?
I usually will try to spend time with family that doesn't smoke or clean my house.

Well honestly not really no one cares that I'm trying to quit. They just tell me I'ma going to fail and start smoking again but that's just motivation. I smoke the most when I'm at work. And you can smoke in the shop at anytime all day if you want. So it's easy to light one every few minutes if I want.So when I have the feeling of smoking, I just did something else like organize tools, sweep the floors, anything to get my mind off it. I don't really smoke much when I'm at home.
I like your ideas 10169. Your family can also be a great resource to support you in quitting! How motivated are you currently to give it a try?

I am very motivated, but I have to take it slowly. I tried a couple of years ago to stop cold turkey- and I succeeded for 2 weeks. After that, though, I went through a bad case of pneumonia in both of my lungs and had to be hospitalized. I gave in to another craving after I got better, and now I'm stuck all over again. So this time I have to take it slowly so that doesn't happen again.

10153, this does sound like a difficult situation, so I appreciate it even more that you are giving it a try! And it's great that you are turning this into motivation to show everyone that they are wrong. We here at TSP certainly believe that you can do it! It sounds like you already have some great strategies to distract yourself. I also encourage you to use sugarfree gum, candy, toothpicks, or something like that to keep your mouth busy. Do you have family members or just friends you can call for support in difficult situations?

10169, yes I understand. This does not sound like something you would want to happen again. What kind of strategy do you think could work for you? Using nicotine replacement (e.g. gum or patch)? Gradually reducing your number of cigarettes? Or something different altogether?

I believe that gradually reducing combined with extra effort to find distractions will work for me. I've tried replacements, but it's not about the nicotine so much as the habit of puffing that is my personal issue. The e cigs don't work either, because since they never go out I constantly puff them.

10169 it's great to hear that you are motivated and willing to try gradually reducing. Some things you could try there: Pick certain cigarettes you want to eliminate (e.g. the first or last one each day, a cigarette after a meal), you could also think about declaring smoke free zones to get you to smoke less (e.g. stop smoking in your car). Yet another way would be to gradually increase the time interval between cigarettes. Which of these strategies may work for you?
I believe all of them combined will help me the best. Thank you .

Sure, you're welcome 10169. I encourage you to set targets or goals of your daily number of cigarettes and start keeping track. Also don't forget to reward yourself if you are meeting your goals to keep up the motivation - very important! Please let me know how it is going over the next couple of weeks and get in touch if you have any questions. You can do it!
I've got to run guys. Tomorrow, I will start with a series of extra smoking cessation advice sessions, so feel free to stop by of you're interested. Bye - see you soon!

#12: When you’re quitting, your friends and family may be eager to help out in any way that they can. Pick your favorite option below or suggest your own. Why would this option be helpful to you? #support • Go places where smoking is not allowed• Send you daily/weekly words of encouragement• Quit smoking with you
Quit smoking with me
Go places smoking isn't allowed, so I don't have the temptation.

#11: Now that you’ve shared about your top reasons for quitting, let’s consider your top reason NOT to quit. Post your #1 Con for quitting and tell us why it’s your biggest concern. You can finish this sentence: "I want to quit smoking, but I'm worried that ________."Feel free to discuss with other group members your concerns about quitting. #freeyourself
I want to quit smoking but it will totally blow not having a smoke after eating or having one while I drink.
I want to quit smoking but it's the only thing I have to myself and gives me a moment to myself.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created an event for 2014-15 Getting Ready to Quit 4.
data.name: The Doctor Is In
data.caption: The Doctor Is In
data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be tomorrow. See you!

data.message: #9: Write a list of all the reasons why you want to quit, and post it somewhere prominent where you will frequently see it. Which spot did you choose, and why will it work for you? #reinforcement

I wrote my list and posted it in my living room, where not only I will see it, but my son and his father can see it as well. It's so that they will know how serious I am about making a change, as well as a reminder to myself whenever it gets hard to go through with it.

#8: Check out this site to see just how much $ you've given to Big Tobacco. Share your numbers here and vow to stop throwing away your hard-earned cash! #beingconscious http://www.cancer.org/healthy/toolsandcalculators/calculators/app/cigarette-calculator
2 packs a week or 42 cigs a week. It's about $10 and change a week.
I generally smoke 120 ciggarettes a week. 50 or 60 bucks a week. Wasted.

#7: Flavored cigarettes have been outlawed for years now, yet e-cig companies are using old tricks to gain new customers while they still can. Would you have started smoking at an earlier age if the product you used was flavored like your favorite candy? #ecig
Personally, no. I don't like cigarettes to taste like anything other than regular or mint. Something fruity- just the thought makes my stomach turn. I think candy should be eaten, not inhaled.
No, because at a younger age I wanted nothing to do  with cigarettes or tobacco what so ever. And now that I am smoking I'm not a fan of the flavored e cigs. Or e cigs in general.
And besides, I'm sure just buying the candy would be way cheaper. Lol

#6: For any of you who aren’t sure what e-cigs are, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing or “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious
data.name: Electronic Cigarettes (e-Cigarettes)
data.caption: fda.gov
data.description: Electronic cigarettes, also known as e-cigarettes, are battery-operated products designed to deliver nicotine, flavor and other chemicals. They turn chemicals, including highly addictive nicotine, into an aerosol that is inhaled by the user.

data.message: If I were a minor I would believe it would be a safer alternative, but not necessarily a better alternative.
I would have believed it would be safer, and would probably have tried it just because it was something new to me.
And plus, if I was a minor, I would love the idea of not smelling like smoke so my parents wouldn't find out lol.
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII
Do you have any thoughts on American spirit ciggarettes? Seeing  as they label there selves as addictive free and organic.

Good question 10153! Unfortunately there is nothing that suggests these kind of cigarettes that brand themselves as "organic" are any less dangerous or harmful, since the combustion of tobacco is really the harmful part. For all we know this is just a marketing twist of the tobacco industry. If you are interested, there is more information on this topic online http://tobacco.stanford.edu/tobacco_main/images.php?token2=fm_st124.php&token1=fm_img3610.php&theme_file=fm_mt010.php&theme_name=Fresh,%20Pure,%20Natural%20&%20Toasted&subtheme_name=Organic
What do you think about this?

Interesting. Thank you.I have one more question for you.Which would you prefer the best way to quit smoking? I've been trying to just cold turkey stop, I've even tried using a vape, to no advantage. It seems very difficult to have the will to quit when I work in a shop where half the employees smoke freely when they want.

That’s the million dollar question :) There are several aspects to it: 1. I would recommend to pick a quit day and following through with it. 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations (sounds like breaks at work are those kinds of situations for you). 4. Depending on how much you smoke I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.). I know this sounds like a lot, but we will cover each of these aspects more in depth over the next weeks. How does this sound? Anything there you think may be useful?
Sorry, I've got to run. Next week I will also start with a series of special smoking cessation advice sessions - so stay tuned for that. See you next week!
Thank you

#5: Big tobacco companies aim to make their brand appealing. Become more conscious and learn to critique cigarette ads. In the ads below, how is Camel trying to manipulate its customers? #beingconscious
I believe they are trying to put out the message to both genders that it is sexy and becoming of both genders to smoke and look "cool".
The pic on the left is pretty much saying only the cool kids are smoking. One on the right is telling  you smoking is sexy.
#4: Take this test to see how addicted to nicotine you are. What’s your reaction to your score? Are you surprised? #beingconscious
data.name: Assess Your Risk - Fagerstrom Test for Nicotine Dependence
data.caption: nova.edu
data.description: Several questions you completed on the smoking questionnaire can be added together to give us an idea of your level of dependence on nicotine. Higher scores typically reflect higher dependence on nicotine.

data.message: My score is 4- Moderately Dependent. I am not really surprised, as I know that I don't HAVE to smoke nearly as often as most people, but I do have times where I don't want to give up the opportunity. I don't have a problem spending the whole day in a no smoking zone, but as soon as I get out I feel as though I need to smoke.

data.message: #2: Why is quitting smoking important to you? Is there anything that would make it even more important? #motivation

I want to quit for my son, so he doesn't pick up the habit later and so he wont be anywhere near smoke or where there has been smoke. I don't think that there could be anything more important than that to me.
^^Same thing and I'm tired of being winded so easily.
These are great and important reasons to quit. Thanks for sharing!
#3: Have any of you used a quit program or counseling program before? There are lots of free programs out there - how could they benefit you? What would make them better? #beingconscious

No- I don't use any of those because I believe that they won't work for me. I don't want to wear patches or chew horrible tasting gum to quit. I would rather it be something fun, like this program has been for me. Something that doesn't just tell you what to do, but offers insight and takes time with you.
Nope.
#1: On a scale of 1-10, how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #motivation
10. As it should be for anyone.

Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Thank you for joining us -- we're so excited to have you here. As you can see, we've started posting TODAY (see #1)! Here's how it works:1) We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on your notifications and check this page daily!2) Your group has been randomly assigned to a Monthly Incentive. To earn money, you must comment on ALL posts we share each month (30 days). You will earn $30 if you've commented on all 30 posts, and $0 if you haven't. We'll tally your comments every 30 days, and you'll have a new chance to earn money at the start of the next month. You will receive a gift card for the money you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.3) Dr. Johannes Thrul will be joining us for 1 hour each week, during which he will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for his first session next week!
Great! Let's get this show on the road
Hello TSP members! Thanks for your patience as we continue to enroll people into this group. The wait will soon be over -- we'll be launching within a week! :D

Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! We're so happy to have you join us and can't wait to start. We're still adding people to this secret group, but in the meantime please check out our Consent Form and TSP Group Rules (click the "Files" link above or scroll down this page). Also, feel free to ask us any questions you may have about the study. Thanks for your patience and stay tuned!

This group is for 18-25 year olds who currently smoke and are ready to quit in the very near future. While your quit-date approaches, get educated about Nicotine Replacement Therapies, ways to prepare for and deal with cravings & triggers, grow your support system and learn the best techniques to quit and STAY quit. This group has been randomly selected to have Monthly Incentives; you can accumulate $30 at the end of every month in which you comment every day, for a gift card of up to $90 at the end of the session.

data.message: First I'm interested to find out a little about your smoking habits: How much are you smoking right now? Like how many cigs per day? How many days a week?
Right now none. But it's only been two days.
Very good - so you are still on track - great! How is your second smokefree day going? Any difficult situations you want to discuss?
Ita irritating. I usually smoke when I'm bored or not doing much and it's usually while running a machine at work. So not having one during those times is the most irritable part
Ok, I see. How have you been dealing with this for the last two days? Which strategies have you been using and how did they work?
Are you still with me 10153?

Sorry was in the gym.And dealing with my two year old. In fact goin to the gym is what really motivates me. Before I started smoking I was in the best Shape I've ever been. And when I started it was getting easier to skip the gym.But I just wanna grow now and I won't make it easy of I continue smoking.

No worries - I have posted all the content here so feel free to check it out. Also, feel free to reach out if you need some advice or support during the next couple of days. The next session will be next week. See you then - take care and keep up the good work!
I spent over a year not going into the gym with smoking and i took a 15lb lost. It's disgusting to think about.

2. GET SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT:- Tell your family, friends and coworkers you are quitting.- Talk to your doctor or other health care provider.- Get group, individual, or telephone counseling.Who can support you with quitting smoking?

10153, I have thought a little more about what you told me yesterday, about how you don’t have people to support you in your quitting efforts. Two things came to mind: If you can’t get people to actively support you, you may at least be able to get them to not interfere with your quitting. For example you could ask them to not offer you cigarettes or to stop smoking while you are around. I have found that people are generally accepting when someone stakes a stand and communicates their decision assertively (we will also talk more about this one of the future sessions). Also, I encourage you to reach out to your fellow TSP group members and to TSP staff (e.g. me) if you need social support in difficult situations. I will also work with you some more on coming up with alternatives for smoking in high-risk situations. How does this sound? Any of these seem suggests seem like they may work for you?

I agree with openly asking them to not smoke around me could help and they will be understanding.And friends tell me I'ma just start smoking again ina few days but I don't let that get to me. I'm doing this for me not for anyone else.

data.story: Johannes Thrul created the event Session 1 - Smoking cessation advice.

data.message: I am getting ready to start with the first smoking cessation advice session. Attending these will really increase your chances of quitting tobacco (if you desire to do so), so feel free to stop by.
Hi everyone, I have posted the content of today's session on the wall of this event - go check it out if you are interested. I will hold the next session next week.
That’s all for today’s session! Please let me know if you have any questions and have a great week!

5. BE PREPARED FOR RELAPSE OR DIFFICULT SITUATIONS:- Avoid alcohol- Be careful around other smokers- Improve your mood in ways other than smoking- Eat a healthy diet and stay activeWhich of these will be most helpful to you?
What do you think you could do in a difficult situation, like drinking with friends who smoke?

4. GET MEDICATION AND USE IT CORRECTLY:Talk with your health care provider about which medication will work best for you:- Medication: bupropion, varenicline (prescription).- Nicotine Replacement: gum & patch (over-the-counter), inhaler & nasal spray (prescription)Are there one of these that you think would be helpful for you?

3. LEARN NEW SKILLS AND BEHAVIORS.- When you first try to quit, change your routine.- Reduce stress.- Distract yourself from urges to smoke.- Plan something enjoyable to do every day.- Drink a lot of water and other fluids.Which of these will be most helpful to you?

To finish up, I want to share with you 5 steps that can guide you make a plan when you’re ready to quit:1. GET READY: Set a quit date and stick to it – not even a single puff!When do you think you will be ready?
10153, again, you have already quit - great job and keep it up!

I want to show you something we call the “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log. (Not so much relevant for you 10153, since you have already quit, but I still want to post it here so other group members can check it out).

You can use it to better understand your smoking by tracking your pleasant activities, mood, and cigs smoked each day.You should keep it in a place where you can see it every day and notice pleasant activities, mood (faces) and cigs.
So, where is the best place for you?... An image on your phone? A photo on FB? Printing it and putting in on your fridge or bathroom mirror??

The goal is to notice patterns in your pleasant activities, mood, and cigs, so it's important to track them often.As you are thinking about quitting, you want to increase your pleasant activities – this will help you with your mood and with quitting cigarettes.

Also, I want you to take another quick survey, this time about your reasons for quitting: https://ucsf.co1.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_bHfZzczARW9HBOJWhen you’re done, tell me which categories you scored a 9 or higher.

data.message: Hi guys, this is Dr. Johannes Thrul from TSP. Are you ready to get started with your first session?
Hell yeah
Great 10153 - let's get started!

data.message: I am getting ready to start with the second smoking cessation advice session. Today, we will talk about high risk situations for smoking and how you can counter them - feel free to stop by.
Hi everyone - we had a great session today. Please check out the materials I have posted in this event - maybe it can be useful for you as well. See you next week!
That’s all for this session!! I am proud of you all! Between now and next session, please continue to keep your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” up-to-date.
Have a good week! Good luck for your quit day 10132 - stay strong 10153! See you guys next week and feel free to reach out if anything comes up.
Thank you!

It’s important to remind yourself and others for why you’re quitting. In our last few minutes, how about each of you say why we are quitting to share with each other and help feel better about doing this hard thing together. So…why are you quitting? What’s the most important reason?
My health.
My son. And my health.

Once you’ve had your last cigarette, I encourage you all to refer to a table that I call “After Your Last Cigarette.” It explains what to expect after having your last cig—from 20 mins after to 5 yrs after! Here’s what it looks like:
I recommend taping it to your fridge/mirror, and posting it on your FB page telling everyone where you are on the table based on how long you’ve quit.

Being prepared with a plan for identifying high-risk situations and knowing how you will successfully cope with them can help to prevent slips or relapses. To make your plan:• Identify your high risk situations.• Develop effective strategies to avoid smoking a cigarette in each high risk situation.• Anticipate upcoming high risk situations and be prepared to use the strategies you’ve developed.

Some strategies for these situations include: having a substitute (gum, candy), have mental distractions from thinking about cigarettes (i.e. focusing on what ppl are saying in convos), and leaving the situation (go to gym, etc.)
What’s one high-risk situation that you can put down and your strategy for coping with it?
Once you’ve quit smoking, situations that were triggers for smoking can now be thought of as high-risk situations for relapse to smoking. What can you do to prepare for these high-risk situations?
Not buy monster energy drinks.
Other situations can be: Being with others who are smoking, feeling down or being in a bad mood, talking with friends, and socializing where others are drinking/using drugs.
Has anyone experienced any withdrawal symptoms yet as you quit/tried to quit/reduced smoking?
After the first few days I was just getting chronic headaches. That's about it though honestly.
How did you cope with those symptoms?
If you haven’t already, try these strategies if you notice any withdrawal symptoms.
I'd take an ibuprofen usually
What triggers led you to smoke this week? What was going on?
Stress basically, I'm arguing with my mother, as well as my roommate. Always worrying, about everything.
Thanks for sharing 10132! That sounds stressful! What strategies other than smoking could you use that can help you deal with stress?
I'm actually not sure, exercise?

That's a great idea - 10132. Some other ideas could be to take a couple of deep breaths, take a walk, drink a nice cup of tea, play a game on your phone - essentially everything that takes your mind off smoking and relaxes you. We will cover deep breathing exercises and imagery to relieve stress in one of the other session - so stay tuned! Anything in my list that sounds useful?
So last time… I suggested that you tell your supporters (family, friends) that you wanted to quit. How did that go?

Still a loner. My girlfriend hasn't helped much considering she asks me if I wanna smoke one when she gets homr everyday .My parents both smoke still although they are happy that I decided to stop, they will still sit and smoke by me. But even though I felt tempted I made myself not bum a cigarette.
Glad to hear you are still right on track and powering through 10153!
Welcome to our 2nd session!  To start off…what is your smoking status (how much you smoke)? What is your quit date (if you have one)?
Pack a day, and the 13th.
Hi 10132 - great that you have set a quit date already!
Yes I really want this.
Let’s review the Mood Log.  Remember this?
What are your stats for today? (Mood, pleasant activities, number of cigs smoked)

data.message: Hi my names 10132, so I normally smoke about a pack a day. Last week I was doing really well down to 2 cigarettes a day, but this week I'm back to normal, I feel like I failed. What tips do you have on sticking with it?

Hi 10132 - this session is supposed to start tomorrow - but since I am online now I am going to give you a couple of recommendations. First of all: Great job! You were able to reduce your smoking quite dramatically for an entire week. You should focus on this accomplishment and I think that shows you that you can really do it if you want. I can try to help you being a bit more strategic about your next try. Here are 5 points I generally recommend (these are also listed in last weeks session): 1. Pick a quit day and following through with it. 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations. 4. I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.). I know this sounds like a lot, but we can work on breaking them down into smaller steps. Any initial thoughts about any of this? Do you think some of these strategies may work for you?
Yes those 5 steps sound like a perfect guideline for me! Do you have any recommendations of nicotine replacement?

I generally recommend nicotine patch and gum. Lozenge is an option as well if you prefer that. All of these are available over the counter so you can get them at every pharmacy. State smoking quit lines can sometimes provide you with a free supply of patch and gum. You can google "your state" & quitline to find out more or call 1-800-QUITNOW. Do you think this is something you would want to try?
Yes, I haven't tried any nicotine replacement before. Your so helpful thank you!

Sure - anytime. Glad I can support you! I am about to go offline for today, but feel free to stop by tomorrow from 5.15-6 PM (Pacific) or next week and check out your local pharmacy or give the quitline a call! It's great that you have decided to try to quit smoking and we at TSP are here to help you! See you soon.
Tomorrow I will be on :) thank you again.
Great - see you tomorrow!
That’s it for today’s session. Anything that may be helpful to you, 10153? Between now and next time, practice being assertive. You can do it!
Ok, sorry I have to run. I'll check in with you next week. Keep up the good work. See you next time! Bye.
Today I thought I could talk a bit about "support" and quitting. We have talked about this before 10153, so I think what I will cover today will be relevant for you.
What are some things others can do that would be helpful to you while you become smoke-free? What can you ask them to do to support you?
Well my girlfriend has decided.today that she has quit to. So that helps out a lot now.
That's great to hear! Having a partner in crime can be very helpful!
Yes indeed. I feel like this is going to be much easier now.
Yes - you guys will be able to help each other!
Everyone is not the same personality. There are many personal styles of communicating:First is the passive style. Here’s a list:
Next there’s the aggressive style:
There’s one last personality type—the ASSERTIVE type:
Which personality type would you say you are?

By being assertive, you have the best chance of getting what you want and you will feel better about yourself by stating/responding that way.BUT…being assertive does not mean that you always have to speak your mind in every situation.Are there any situations in your pursuit of quitting smoking where you guys would like to be more assertive?
I feel like I fall into the assertive type and an agressive style.

How would you handle the following situations without smoking?1. You’re at a party with a group of friends. Your friends are smoking.You’re feeling relaxed and thinking about how you always used to smoke at parties.Just as you start to say to yourself, “A cigarette would sure be good now,” your friend offers you a cigarette.What would you do or say?
I wouldn't take one knowing I've decided to quit although thr temptation would be very great.

Sometimes you may have to respond by revealing to others how their behavior/comments make you feel. There are 3 steps to being successful with this: 1. Be neutral when describing their behavior to them2. Use “I feel” statements to describe how you feel about their comments/behavior3. Let them know what you want from them (i.e. a specific behavior change) that can help you as you quitHow do you think you could use these 3 steps in your situations to respond assertively?

Although other people may not always change their behavior upon your request, using these steps gives you a better chance of getting what you want and will leave you feeling better about yourself and your ability to be assertive.

How would you handle the following situations without smoking?2. You just got out of school. A bunch of your friends are hanging out on the side of the school.You watch as someone in the group pulls out a pack of your favorite cigarettes and lights up.You smell the smoke and think about how you always used to enjoy a cigarette after school.Your friend notices that you’re looking at the cigarette, holds out the pack says, “Want one?”What would you do or say?

Think positively about your decision to refuse a cigarette.It is easy to go along with what everyone else is doing.You are someone who makes a decision to do something and sticks to it!Respect yourself, and you will earn the respect of others in the long run.
Here’s a pic you can use to remind you of the tips
Here’s another tip: Respond confidently.
How can these tips work for you?

One of the biggest challenges for an ex-smoker is declining a cigarette offer. Developing and practicing effective ways to turn down cigarette offers will reduce the chances of getting caught off guard.What are some situations where you might be offered a cigarette?
What triggers led you to smoke this week? What was your mood? Who were you with?
Welcome to the third session. How has it been for you this week? When was the last time you smoked?
Today
I messed up an gave in. Am not having the best start of the week. But it was only one cigarette today .

Thanks for sharing 10153. Lapses are sometimes part of the smoking cessation process and nothing to be ashamed of. You already mentioned the important thing: It was only one and it's still up to you if you continue smoking the next one or if you go back to quitting. How do you feel about your quitting now?
I don't feel too as bad as if I were to go and buy some. It wasn't worth it. It was actually kind of gross. Considering I haven't smoked in a while.
Think of your slip as a mistake. One cigarette doesn’t make you a smoker again. Remind yourself of the hard work you’ve done towards quitting and choose not to smoke the next cigarette!

data.message: Alright, that’s it for today’s session. In our last session next week we will review some of the most important tips to quit smoking and will talk about how to maintain long-term motivation to stay smoke-free. See you next week! Bye.
Before I wrap up, do you have any questions around anything we have talked about today?

Another important issue around weight and quitting is #2: making HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES. Knowledge about healthy food choices is helpful to new quitters because:• Ex-smokers tend to eat more sugary foods than they did while smoking.• Increased sugar can produce mood swings and can “sap” one’s energy.• Food often tastes and smells better when someone has quit smoking.• Some people use food as a substitute for tobacco when they try to quit.Does any of this apply to any of you?
I will admit I'm not the healthiest eater.
Maybe you find some of these recommendations useful:
What do you think would be practical for you in this area? What would be challenging?
The fast food is what is killing me everyday for lunch. I'm not sure what you mean

Do you have any alternatives for your lunch? Some options may be leftovers from the night before or a somewhat healthier fast food option (in case one is available of course). Do you have any ideas what could work for you?

Left over would be ideal for me. I should make time to prep meals but it never happens like I want to. Not to mention most of what I cook isn't the healthiest either. Louisiana people love us some seasoning.

Haha, I see :) one way to go about it would be to start slowly - I wouldn't aim for bringing leftovers every day to start with, but maybe you can start by trying to do it once a week and if it works increase the number of days slowly. Just an idea.
Honestly I'm too lazy to prep meals. It's another change I know I have to make. 2 year Olds are exhausting. Haha.

Another important issue around quitting smoking is #3: Alcohol and Drug Use: Big-Time Triggers for SmokingFor most smokers, where they drink or do drugs they will also smoke. If your goal is to quit smoking, you should think very seriously about how you will deal with situations where you might drink alcohol or use drugs.What are your options?
I rarely drink as it is. Not good to dehydrate the muscles.Drugs were never an option.

We all come in different shapes and sizes. In our society, TV and other media tend to portray an extremely thin body as the ideal body type.  However, it is not realistic or healthy for everyone to look that way. A more realistic goal is to have a fit body, no matter your body type. By choosing to quit smoking, you are making a healthy lifestyle choice. You are choosing to be a strong, fit and healthy person.How do you feel about that?
What are your current goals with regard to exercise?
I'm hoping to put on 10 more pounds. Lol

During this session, I’d like you to think about one goal you’ll set for yourself this week. First we are going to talk about an important issue around quitting smoking: Body weight concerns. Any reaction to this topic off the bat?
Since I've quit I've gained 12 pounds. But they are the good gains. Going to the gym feels a lot better.

So weight gain is actually a good thing in your case 10153 :)  most people have exactly the opposite problem. Let's take a look at how exercise can help you with quitting - and it sure looks like you are already doing quite a bit of that.
#1: EXERCISE (which can be particularly helpful to you as you quit smoking). Here’s how exercise can help you quit:
What are some of your favorite ways to exercise?
Here are more ways that exercise can help with not smoking:
Which of these do you think helps you the most?
I weight lift and body build. Don't do much cardio or any of that. And so far since I've quit I'm not winded so easily. I eat more. Definantly helps with the gains

Welcome to session 5.Did you comment on your “Daily Tracking of Smoking, Mood, and Activities” log?How many cigarettes you smoked (if any), number of pleasant activities, and your general mood? If you didn’t keep track, take your best guess.
